thread.title: South Alabama midseason report: Jaguars still have chance to make noise in Sun Belt race
thread.title_full: South Alabama midseason report: Jaguars still have chance to make noise in Sun Belt race

author: Creg Stephenson | cstephenson@al.com
title: South Alabama midseason report: Jaguars still have chance to make noise in Sun Belt race
text:
Comments 
South Alabama is halfway through its 2015 regular season, having finished up the first half at 3-3 overall and 1-1 in the Sun Belt Conference 
The Jaguars had a bye Saturday, and will next be in action Oct. 24 at Texas State. He's a breakdown of how South Alabama has fared in the various phases of the game thus far: 
Offense 
UAB transfer Cody Clements has stepped right in and given the Jaguars a productive passing attack, averaging 234 yards a game with 10 touchdown passes. On the negative side, he's thrown nine interceptions, including a couple of late-game killers. 
Now that all four are in the lineup together, Josh Magee, D.J. Vinson, Marvin Shinn and Danny Woodson give the Jaguars an experienced and productive receiver corps. Tight Gerald Everett is probably the best player on the team and one of the best at his position in the country. 
The running game has not fared as well, ranking near the bottom of the Sun Belt at just 119.4 yards per game. Xavier Johnson has been solid, but was slowed against Arkansas State by a heel injury. 
The offensive line has also been a mixed bag, at times struggling mightily to protect Clements. Right guard Cameron Blankenship, arguable the Jaguars' best player up front, is out 2-3 weeks following knee surgery . 
RELATED: South Alabama looking to bounce back after fourth-quarter collapse against Arkansas State 
Defense 
The statistics are skewed a bit by blowout losses against Nebraska and North Carolina State, but the Jaguars have been mostly good defensively, particularly considering all the new faces on that side of the ball. 
The linebacker corps, led by top tackler Blake Dees, UAB transfer Kalen Jackson and freshman Bull Barge, has been excellent. Jackson in particular has been a revelation at Will linebacker, despite weighing just 200 pounds. 
The Jaguars have struggled on the defensive line, both in getting pressure on the quarterback (just six sacks this season) and in being pushed around by physical running games. Jack linebacker Akeem Lewis missed two games with a toe injury, but returned to play well against Arkansas State before a targeting ejection. 
The secondary has performed admirably at times, but continues to be victimized by the big play. True freshman Jalen Thompson looks like a future standout at cornerback, however. 
Special teams 
Aleem Sunanon has been largely reliable, hitting all 15 extra points and making 9 of 11 field goals (though he did miss a 28-yarder against Troy). He's even filled in a bit at punter. 
Beyond Sunanon, the kicking game has been a disaster for the Jaguars. Punter Brandon McKee has averaged just 39.5 yards, and was pulled late in the Arkansas State game in favor of Sunanon. 
The Jaguars' return teams have not been good, averaging only 20.3 yards on kickoffs and an almost impossibly puny 2.0 yards on punts. Kickoff coverage has been decent, but punt coverage — opponents average 16.2 yards per return — has also been shaky. 
Remaining schedule 
The Jaguars should be favored to win their next two games, at Texas State Oct. 24 and at home against Idaho Nov. 7. A Nov. 12 Thursday night home game against Louisiana-Lafayette could be the key to the season. 
Win those three, and South Alabama would be in position to top last year's victory total (6) when it travels to Georgia State on Nov. 21. The Jaguars are likely to be underdogs against Georgia Southern Nov. 28 and Appalachian State Dec. 5. 
Bottom line 
While the Jaguars missed a golden opportunity to jump into the Sun Belt race when it blew a fourth-quarter lead against Arkansas State Tuesday night, the season is not off the rails by any means. The next three weeks will tell the tale of the 2015 South Alabama football team.
